text.p: Eurotunnel Plc/SA, the debt-laden operator of the Channel tunnel, Tuesday confirmed it would slash 657 jobs out of a total just under 3,500.
The job cuts are part of wider reorganization at the Anglo-French company, which will lead to 32 million pounds ($40 million) in savings this year.

The Anglo-French company said the job cuts mainly affected consultants, sub-contractors and temporary staff. Staff on indefinite contracts will be trimmed by 290, with Eurotunnel trying to redeploy workers elsewhere in the company.
Of all jobs earmarked to be slashed, 306 will go in London and Folkestone in Britain, while the remaining 351 will be scrapped in Paris and Coquelles in France.
The job cuts were widely expected after Eurotunnel said Monday that a string of media reports on job losses were "broadly correct."

Money-losing Eurotunnel, which has succeeded in gaining an almost 50 percent share of cross-Channel traffic in its first two years of operation, said it was essential it improved its competitiveness and offer the best service at the lowest cost.
